fields.value: Predictors of Activism and Radicalism: Past Activism, Past Radicalism and Grievance Against the Government

authorAffiliation.value: Bryn Mawr College.  Department of Psychology.

dsDescriptionValue.value: The study aimed at testing the relationship between grievance, activism and radicalism. Researchers gathered 429 participants from across the United States and randomly divided them into two experimental conditions. One group was given questions about past and future intention to engage in activism-radicalism first, followed by questions about any grievance against the US government; the other group was given grievance questions came first, followed by questions about activism and radicalism. Questions from the study were designed in order to determine how past behavior may relate to future behavior in regards to activism and radicalism. The major variables that were included in this study were demographics, future/past activism, grievances with the United States government, and attitudes toward U.S. law enforcement.

publicationCitation.value: Moskalenko, S., & McCauley, C. (2009). Measuring political mobilization: The distinction between activism and radicalism. Terrorism and Political Violence, 21(2), 239-260.

fields.value: Subject: Study Level Error Note, Notes: This survey excludes the portion of the United States population that cannot be reached by telephone, as well as 6% to 8% of the United States population that does not live within the WebTV Internet Service Provider network;

grantNumberAgency.value: National Consortium for the Study of Terrorism and Responses to Terrorism (START). U.S. Department of Homeland Security.

distributorName.value: Time-Sharing Experiments for the Social Sciences

otherGeographicCoverage.value: United States (Alabama, Alaska, Arizona, Arkansas, California, Colorado, Connecticut, Delaware, Florida, Georgia, Hawaii, Idaho, Illinois, Indiana, Iowa, Kansas, Kentucky, Louisiana, Maine, Maryland, Massachusetts, Michigan, Minnesota, Mississippi, Missouri, Montana, Nebraska, Nevada, New Hampshire, New Jersey, New Mexico, New York, North Carolina, North Dakota, Ohio, Oklahoma, Oregon, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island, South Carolina, Tennessee, Texas, Utah, Virginia, Washington, West Virginia, Wisconsin, Wyoming)

value: All adults in the United States with access to a telephone.

fields.value: The study involved 429 subjects from across the United States in a two-by-two between subjects experimental design. Participants were randomly divided into four conditions. In the first condition, questions about past and future intention to engage in activism-radicalism were asked first, followed by questions about attitudes toward law enforcement, and concluded with questions about any grievance against the United States government. In the second condition, law enforcement questions came first, followed by questions about activism and radicalism, and concluded with grievance questions. In the third condition, grievance questions came first, followed by law enforcement questions, and concluded with questions concerning activism and radicalism. In the fourth condition, grievance questions came first, followed by questions concerning activism and radicalism, and concluded with questions concerning law enforcement. There were 105 respondents per condition, for a total of 7920 respondent-questions.

Seven post-stratification weights are incorporated into this study. The first is half-sampling of telephone numbers for which no address could be found. The second is RDD sampling rates proportional to the number of phone lines in the household. The third is minor oversampling of Chicago and Los Angeles due to early pilot surveys in these two cities. The fourth is short-term double-sampling of the four largest states (CA, NY, FL, and TX) and central region states. The fifth is under-sampling of households not covered by MSN TV. The sixth is oversampling of minority households (Black and Hispanic). Finally, the seventh weight is the selection of one adult per household. In order to calculate final weights, the researchers derived weighted sample distributions along various combinations of five variables. The first is gender (male, female). The second is age (18-29, 30-44, 45-59, 60 and over). The third is race/ethnicity (White, Black, other, Hispanic). The fourth is region (northeast, Midwest, south, west). Finally, the fifth variable is education (highest level achieved: less than high school, high school, some college, college degree or more). Similar distributions are calculated using the most recent U.S. Census Bureau's Current Population Survey data and the Knowledge Network panel data. Cell-by-cell adjustments over the various univariate and bivariate distributions are calculated to make the weighted sample cells match those of the U.S. Census and the Knowledge Network panel.
